Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Small: Fundamental Limitations for Classes of Cooperative Multi-Agent Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to study such properties of classes of cooperative multi-agent systems as stability, performance, and robustness. Multi-agent systems such as vehicle platoons and coupled oscillators can display emergent behavior that is difficult to predict from the behavior of individual subsystems. The approach is to develop and extend the theory of fundamental design limitations to cover multi-agent systems that communicate over both physical and virtual communication links. The theory will further describe known phenomena, such as string instability, and extend the analysis to other systems, such as harmonic oscillators. The theory will be tested and validated in the Michigan Embedded Control Systems Laboratory.


The intellectual merit of the proposed research will be the development of tools that delineate tradeoffs between performance and feedback properties for control systems involving mixes of human and computer agents and classes of hardware dynamics, controllers, and network topology. The contribution to system behavior of each agent?s realization in hardware (constrained by Newton's laws) and realization in software and communications (subject to the constraints discovered by Shannon and Bode) will be assessed.


The broader impacts of the proposed research will be a significant impact on teaching, both at the University of Michigan and at ETH Zurich. At each school, popular teaching laboratories allow over 100 students per year, from diverse backgrounds, to learn concepts from the field of embedded networked distributed control systems. New families of haptic devices will enable the research to be transferred into these teaching laboratories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the introduction of embedded microprocessors in so many machines today, the control interfaces that humans use to operate and steer machines are undergoing dramatic changes. Pushbutton interfaces are giving way to touchscreens, steering columns are being replaced by steer-by-wire systems, and levers linked mechanically to flight control surfaces are now linked electronically instead.  Embedded control offers advantages in economy, programmability, customizability, and system performance and can also be used to add features like active safety and automatic control. But when a mechanical (physical) linkage is replaced by an electronic (cyber) linkage, certain undesirable phenomena can arise that may be difficult to anticipate. In simple cases the lack of dissipativity in the cyber link unmasks instabilities that were present but suppressed in the system with the physical link. In more complex cases, there may be no simple physical equivalent to the system containing the cyber link, and a dissipative element that could otherwise be used to provide stability guarantees may be difficult to identify. Also, when the forces reflected naturally through a physical link are not replicated in the cyber link, important information about machine behavior may no longer be available to the human operator. Moreover, the human operator's body is no longer dynamically coupled to the machine or task dynamics in the same manner.

The major goal of this project has been to develop appropriate models and accompanying control theory to describe phenomena arising in cyberphysical systems that do not have correlates in purely physical systems. In particular, we have set out to develop and apply fundamental limitations theory to cyberphysical and human-in-the-loop systems, initially concentrating our efforts on two systems: 1) a set of oscillators coupled and driven by automatic controllers in various open chain or "string" configurations, and 2) simple loads, masses, and oscillators driven by human operators.

A system of coupled oscillators is closely related to the system of coupled masses often used to model a platoon of vehicles. A significant body of prior work exists for vehicle platoons, including string stability results based on fundamental limitations theory. We have successfully extended these results to cover systems of coupled oscillators, with potential application in biological systems and formation flying control.  

We have also developed a simple model of human motor behavior that describes the contribution of both the central nervous system and the mechanics of the body to movement against loads that may be expected or unexpected. Lifting an object that is either lighter or heavier than expected produces characteristic excursions in the lift trajectory that we have all experienced at one time or another. But to date no model of human motor behavior has attempted to describe what portion of that excursion is due to an inappropriate motor plan or due to the bending of the arm and musculature under load. Naturally the arm and musculature has a finite mechanical impedance that will "give” under load. We developed a model that combines neural control with biomechanics. We tested this model using human subject experiments that combined system identification and input estimation techniques and included loads that were expected and unexpected.

The major conclusion of this analysis is that the addition of haptic feedback to a virtual environment or cyber link significantly changes the power flow between the virtual world and human user. A human user does not behave as an ideal force or motion source; rather a user acts on their environment through a body with finite mechanical impedance. But that mechanical impedance is accounted for in motion plans, in that its bending under expected loads is accommodated using feedforward control.
